AE5B137F75484749B015033783742F7B.description: Adds details and new elements to dramatic play situations.
comments: Gets more props for her friends.
Uses the blanket as a table cloth at the restaurant.
Plays the wolf in The Three Little Pigs.
Says, "My grandfather told me a story about the wind. I'll be the wind."

D8A389426A844670AA920BEC348A0A33.description: Pretends an object exists without using a prop.
comments: Orders a veggie pizza and reaches into his pocket for imaginary money to pay for the meal.
Pretends to put on a hat and coat to go outside.

88A0CFE0533448A0B302271C94EC11F2.description: Takes on more than one dramatic play role at a time.
comments: Plays a daddy and a baby by changing his voice.
Says, "I'll be the doctor and the nurse. You be the patient."

0B561A9EA6F34D82964C1C1C65AFC3DB.description: Assumes roles from daily activities using a variety of props.
comments: Selects from a box of clothes a hat, jacket and piece of rope and portrays a firefighter putting out a fire.
Pretends to be a teacher and reads a book to the stuffed bear.
The child uses the portrayal of events, characters, or stories through acting and using props and language to explore and create.

EF0EAF0DE9844B49B9E7754957A97CED.description: Uses creative movement and dance to interpret the mood of various types of music and stories.
comments: Acts out a story.
Twirls a scarf back and forth in the air and moves to the music.

940128BD3B024F1FBC292D15FED35440.description: Responds to different types of music, (e.g., rock, classical, jazz, spirituals, reggae, Native American chants, gospel, bluegrass, lullabies, marches and country music).
comments: Rocks a baby doll when hearing a lullaby.
Says, "I like the music with the drums in it."

3FF7736C9D934E24BB35F3CAD2632388.description: Uses familiar songs, rhymes or chants to create their own musical/movement improvisations.
comments: Makes up her own verse and movements to a favorite song/tune.
Says, "Look, I'm walking like an elephant."

FF7A7633DC964A0292EACC9B68CE4E42.description: Sings and moves to familiar rhymes, songs, and chants.
comments: Marches, slowing down or speeding up with the music.
Sings the "Hello" song.

61AC51A1D1D846FB917008FA36385F12.description: Experiments with a variety of instruments, vocalizations, sounds or creative movements.
comments: Uses voices to make animal sounds.
Uses a tin pie pan and spoon to make a drum.

7856DB6C156B4E909A53F96FF6DF43F2.description: Creates and Understands Music, Movement and Dance
comments: The child uses a wide variety of instruments, movements, techniques and music to explore and create.

B82455BB64A84ABFAB23FA0A22AB5712.description: Seeks an understanding of artwork by self or others by commenting on or questioning the artwork.
comments: Tells a story about the picture she drew.
Asks, "How did you make the clay do that?" when observing another child's sculpture.

DDFD99419BC8467E966FCF62A7D40428.description: Creates art in two and three dimensions.
comments: Uses glue and craft sticks to create a work of art.
Uses twigs to construct a house.

525DB0D509C24F0695EDC136338FBABB.description: Creates art work with details which represent creative and personal choices, ideas, experiences and feelings.
comments: Draws a portrait including facial details.
Draws a picture of where he went for vacation.
Takes the time to select a piece of paper for the desired texture and color.

79D3A39A2C2F42DA9D71B54DD664A9A5.description: Uses a variety of materials/media, tools and techniques to create original works of art (e.g., paper, rocks, sand, clay; tools such as cotton swabs, small/large brushes, drinking straws, and techniques such as drawing, painting, sculpting).
comments: Makes a collage using fabric, torn paper and yarn.
Uses wood scraps with glue to make "constructions."
Uses clay to make a sculpture.
The child uses a wide variety of materials, media, tools, techniques and processes to explore, create and understand art.

The arts nurture the imagination and creative spirit of all children. As children are involved in the arts process they develop independence, self-esteem, and self-expression. The arts connect all areas of learning and are fundamental to children's development and education. The arts enable all children to discover more about who they are and gain insight into their own culture and the cultures around them.

A11019E48875424C92DF7AB4903A2180.description: Identifies how adults help to keep us safe.
comments: Identifies the roles of firefighters and police officers in an emergency situation.
Seeks out teacher when she is hurt or afraid.
Tells a friend to call 911 because the "doll is hurt."
Participates in classroom fire drill routine with adult support and modeling.
Tells a caregiver/teacher her mother's name.
Tells a familiar adult their first and last name.

0C42DAC580D947908C8FEC6232DFF8CA.description: Enforces personal boundaries (safety, self-advocacy and boundary awareness).
comments: Says, "Don't touch me."
Gets the attention (by touch or sound) of a trusted adult when made to feel uncomfortable or unsafe by another person.

5226974E0C9F4544B1B172729672867C.description: Demonstrates transportation and street safety practices.
comments: Waits for an adult to say it's safe to cross the street.
Cooperates using car seat and seat belts in family car or school bus.

55EEA2ABF29C4BF8982DE54E289924A2.description: Identifies and follows basic safety rules with guidance and support; e.g., sun safety, animal and plant safety, outdoor and indoor safety.
comments: Puts on sun protection; e.g., hat and sunglasses before going outside in the sun.
Keeps a safe distance from moving swings.
Says, "When I use a hammer, I wear goggles."
Child demonstrates knowledge of personal safety practices and routines.

6D39891BEEA447A89C63FC040CA741D1.description: Awareness of the functions of body parts.
comments: Identifies function of body parts; e.g., "I hear with my ears." or "I see with my eyes."
Tells a friend, "My muscles make me strong."

Nutrition:
  • Explains why the body needs food; e.g., "to make my body grow."
  • Asks for water while playing outside

Physical activity and rest:
  • Says, "When I run my legs get strong." or "I run fast because I exercise."
  • Takes a break under the shade after running on the playground.
Uses a tissue to wipe nose when needed and throws the tissue away.
Washes and dries hands after using the toilet.
Brushes teeth after meals.
Child demonstrates knowledge of personal health practices, routines and understands the functions of body parts.

A6237FE54D484BDE98F47A900765F50A.description: Uses fine motor skills in daily living.
comments: Buttons, unbuttons, snaps, buckles, laces or ties shoe.
Uses eating utensils at mealtimes.

6A343A09F403439DAA1BE108D35F0AF0.description: Manipulates smaller objects, tools and instruments that require wrist and squeezing motions.
comments: Twists the cap off of a jar.
Uses pencil/crayon to make recognizable shapes, lines and dots.
Cuts paper with scissors.

1E9975675032456695B9FDE0B278DD22.description: Uses eye-hand coordination to perform simple tasks.
comments: Strings large beads.
Hits peg with a wooden hammer.

D52C213B0F7741868FEC2A90DE986853.description: Uses fingers, hands, and wrists to manipulate a variety of tools and materials, (e.g., crayons, markers, chalk, sponges, paint brushes, scissors, pencils, silverware).
comments: Tears paper into pieces to make a collage.
Draws and paints a mural on paper taped to the wall.
The child uses fingers, hands and wrists to manipulate tools and materials.

288517977BF14F81A93834DD3D41AC80.description: Demonstrates spatial awareness in physical activity.
comments: Moves forward, backward and sideways.
Jumps for height and distance.
Kicks, throws and catches a ball.
Pumps swing on outdoor play equipment.

816A730466524133B2C7F5970E56514A.description: Moves with control (e.g., walks, runs, skips, jumps, gallops, hops).
comments: Runs during a game of tag, slowing and accelerating as needed to maneuver around equipment and people.
Walks backward.
Walks along the curb without falling off.
Bends, stretches and twists while playing or exercising.
The child moves with balance, control and coordination.

It is important to recognize that children's physical development and their health and safety have as important a place in the curriculum as other areas of development. Children develop skills necessary for future social and academic success as they explore, combine and refine their physical movements. Children in our care deserve environments that are safe and encourage healthy living. Therefore, it is important to model healthy living practices and teach children the importance of good hygiene, a healthy diet and the need for exercise and rest.

E705DFD3E47C45C19557DAB21042BA37.description: Understands that events happened in the past and how these events relate to one's self, family and community.
comments: Describes a family snow trip while reading The Snowy Day.
Says, "We had a piñata at my party, too."

850718042D3E470D9EEDE76861B9F630.description: Demonstrates an understanding of time in the context of daily experiences.
comments: Tells her mom that her friend was sick yesterday and not at school.
Reminds substitute teacher that they go on the playground after snack in the morning.
Shows the new boy in the class the picture schedule so he knows what comes next.
Describes what happens next in a familiar story.

EEB66904B9FE4D989DD69ADC36DD3E3E.description: Understands Time – Past, Present and Future
comments: The child demonstrates an awareness of time and sequence of events in their daily lives.

78E44DE0179D4000B6CAB0C612D6FF15.description: Describes some physical features of the environment in which the child lives; e.g., bodies of water, mountains, weather.
comments: Says, "There are a lot of mountains where I live."
Says, "It is hot outside."

5B3F355A827341B3B5929817188BE9D9.description: Uses words to describe directionality and/or location within the community.
comments: Says, "We went by the library on our way to the park."
Says, "This is the door that goes outside to the playground."
The child demonstrates an awareness of locations within and around their community.

EAD4631BA10B459086FEF5440CF742F5.description: Describes their role at home, at school, and in the community.
comments: Says, "I am the line leader today."
Says, "I helped my mom count the apples at the grocery store."

635EAEFC50F7435583A7710064C9E569.description: Recognizes that people have wants and must make choices because resources and materials are limited.
comments: Notices that the red paint is gone and asks the teacher to get more out of the supply closet.
Offers to share the sponge in the water table when there is only one available.
Reminds a classmate to use "walking feet" while in the classroom so he won't be hurt.
Explains, "We wash our hands before we eat, so we don't have germs."
Shows a friend how to fold clothes in dramatic play.
Selects a task from the job chart.

298F7BA0AD034117B5D75DD6415C6DD1.description: Recognizes that people rely on others for goods and services; e.g., farm goods, mail delivery, safety or health care.
comments: Pretends to buy or sell food in "grocery store" dramatic play.
Says, "I went to the doctor because I was sick."

5DB2E1CF6DDF48F8BD4D995D1DF1AB1F.description: Shows an understanding of how to care for the environment.
comments: Picks up trash outside and puts paper in the recycling container
Helps to plant flowers.
Assists with setting the table.
Cleans up the play area when appropriate.

28C24F3BB30945359BC4EF9BE5BB7D71.description: Rights, Responsibilities and Roles within Community
comments: The child demonstrates a sense of belonging to the community and contributes to its care.

99485D7CAF9A41379523BA1A87F28516.description: Describes some characteristics (e.g., clothing, food, jobs) of the people in their community.
comments: Describes the clothes worn by dancers at the pow-wow celebration.
Talks about the firefighter they met at their neighborhood fire station.

240AA99E31D74DFBA2CE5E387E83C2DE.description: Identifies, discusses and asks questions about similarities and differences in other people in their community.
comments: Asks, "Why do you eat with chopsticks?"
Says to a peer, "Your skin is a different color than mine."

F249306AB36A434AB04E1EE893F98A46.description: Recognizes that places where people live are made up of individuals from different cultures and who speak different languages.
comments: Says, "Your uncle speaks Navajo."
Says, "My grandma is from Mexico."
The child recognizes that he/she lives in a place with many people and that there are people and events in other places.

561BBBA4DF314270A760A82FB5D3DE98.description: Shows knowledge of family members' roles and responsibilities in the home.
comments: Says, "My big brother cleans up the kitchen after we eat."
Says, "My mom takes me to school."

724DC0C508B146B5B2C83323E6E3951D.description: Develops an awareness of their personal & family history.
comments: Shares information about their adoption.
States, "My mom was in the Army and now she came back home."

632AEB9B80B244308CA6B48911CCB56A.description: Identifies similarities and differences in their family composition and the families of others.
comments: Participates in a chart-making activity showing the number of siblings in each family.
Says, "Your grandmother lives with you and my aunt lives with me."

A2C578F7A19544F7867AF2E41E545C70.description: Describes/discusses own family's cultural or family traditions.
comments: States, "We do that at my house" during a story about a traditional celebration.
Tells another child about a recent family activity; e.g., holiday, birthday, dinner, or wedding.

1074C186BE874D9CBD4AB290C01DC7B4.description: Identifies family members; e.g., mother, father, sister, brother, grandparents, cousins, etc.
comments: Draws a picture of her family.
Points to or names family members in a photograph.

8D445D26206E4A4F896D5FFCAF72CED1.description: Views self as a member of the family unit.
comments: Says, "I'm going on vacation with my family."
Mentions, "I have a baby brother and a big sister."
The child demonstrates an understanding of families and the roles and responsibilities of being a family member.

At a young age, children begin to develop their social identity and think about their place in the social world. As children grow, they develop an increased awareness of their personal histories and heritage, and a sense of time and place.

F0EBFD116E614C92BDF98CA57F6974AA.description: Conducts further investigation based on prior experience and information gained.
comments: Says, "Next time I want to see what happens if I water the plant every day."
Chooses to mix other colors to see if she can get the same shade.

AEFB9DE9D29A4A30A60DB320ADAA2D01.description: Presents their scientific ideas in a variety of ways.
comments: Makes own version of a bird nest with twigs, feathers, and other materials.
Draws a picture of a plant after planting seeds and watching them grow.
Places all floating materials on one tray and all sinking items on another tray during a sink/float activity.
Finds out that marbles roll faster than other items after looking at a chart displaying speeds of various objects.
The child discusses and reflects upon the scientific investigation and its findings.
Concludes that round objects roll down the ramp and flat objects slide down the ramp after placing different objects on a ramp.
Says, "Your plant died because you didn't water it."
Says, "It fell because I let go of the string" while using a pulley to hoist a bucket.
Explains, "When it rains the playground gets muddy."

EE514FCAA8974993867B4756AAB878CF.description: Uses a variety of materials to record and organize data.
comments: Uses journals, drawings or graphs to record information about the plant growth.
Creates a collection of items relevant to an experiment.
The child forms conclusions about observations and experimentations.
Child returns day after day to see if the chicken eggs have hatched.
Child plants seeds and continues to care for them and observes changes.

EDC85C9AE3EF4FD090066797111CC1FF.description: Adjusts the experiment if results are different than expected and continues testing.
comments: Continues to mix different colors of paint to try to make purple.
Looks for another metal object when the magnet will not stick to the coins.

5CDFEDE65CF44E819BE666346B31C592.description: Makes predictions and checks them through hands-on investigation with adult support.
comments: Predicts that the rock will sink when placed in water.
Says, "If I step on the balloon, it will pop."

6DF15302D5CB4374A03601483B635B52.description: Uses a variety of tools and materials to investigate.
comments: Uses various tools to examine insects; e.g., magnifying glass, tongs, or tweezers.
Selects a scale to figure out how many small blocks will weigh as much as a big block.
The child tests predictions through exploration and experimentation.

B953D4C545814D37A54C71C102916CAD.description: Asks and responds to questions about relationships of objects, living things, and events in the natural environment.
comments: Answers, "It will melt," in response to the question, "What do you think will happen if we put the ice in the sun?"
Asks, "What is the nest made of? How did a bird do this without hands?"

A588DA8E8F9342B88C7499690215BF3D.description: Begins to describe the similarities, differences and relationships between objects, living things and natural events.
comments: Places a picture of a baby chick with a hen.
Says, "Your rock is smooth and mine is rough."

4319BC6833D745A0950DDEF6A6C46FEB.description: Describes changes in objects, living things, and the natural events in the environment.
comments: Describes how he is getting bigger.
Says, "When I came to school it was cloudy and now it is sunny."

92E6DC5D2FE842C19A651D671A767B04.description: Identifies attributes of objects, living things, and natural events in the environment.
comments: Notices bean seeds planted in clear bags have sprouted into plants with roots and a stem.
Moves in the sunlight and realizes that her own shadow moves when she moves.

D01D5F96FB3642FBB5EB67E994A6E8DF.description: Exhibits curiosity about objects, living things, and other natural events in the environment by using one or more senses.
comments: Observes a butterfly on a flower with a magnifying glass.
Feels and smells the orange blossoms on the tree in his caregiver's back yard.
The child asks questions and makes predictions while exploring and observing in the environment.

Science, for young children, is an active and open-ended search for new knowledge. As children seek answers, they will plan, observe, predict, and form conclusions. Children's observations, predictions, explanations, and conclusions, correct or incorrect, should be respected and valued by caregivers.

C1812183E2454A329B5CB92CDC0FE105.description: Compares and describes attributes of two- and three- dimensional objects in the environment using own vocabulary.
comments: Describes shapes in a feely box.
Notices and signs, "I see rectangles on the side of my milk carton."
Says, "The ball doesn't have any corners."

C697EA99E0B24248A6AC0088A9440DF3.description: Creates two- and three-dimensional shapes during play.
comments: Uses arms to form a circle to represent the sun.
Uses finger to draw basic shapes in shaving cream or sand.

2ABBE54956494E8F917EA8A160F2D3C5.description: Uses the names of geometric shapes when describing objects found in the environment.
comments: Says, "I have a pink oval," when playing Shape Bingo.
Asks, "May I have another square block?"
Declares, "Look, the stop sign is an octagon."
Points to a door when requested to point to something that is a rectangle.
Exclaims, "My buttons are circles!"
The child recognizes names and describes common shapes and their properties.

C74846A636274E51AD939219CA449EC3.description: Describes the position or location of objects in relation to self or to other objects.
comments: Plays with a car on a road constructed out of blocks and says, "The car is on the road."
Notices a puppy between two children in a magazine picture and says, "The puppy is in the middle."

CC04D6F77FA34AE4A3CFAFF503C07EA6.description: Uses and responds to positional terms (e.g., between, inside, under, above, behind).
comments: Moves next to Javier when asked to stand next to a friend.
Says to his friend, "Please put your milk on the table."
The child uses and demonstrates an understanding of positional terms.

6E4A8984678B4733A576D3ED3450EDD1.description: Uses appropriate vocabulary to describe time and sequence related to daily routines.
comments: Says, "After snack, we go outside."
Responds appropriately when asked, "What did you do this morning?"
Relates a sequence of events from a trip to the store.
Places purple color samples (as from a paint store) in order from lightest to darkest.
Places blocks in order by height.

4B0289C05A994D249C872CA7191C628F.description: Uses various standard measuring tools for simple measuring tasks.
comments: Takes measuring tape and pretends to measure objects in a room.
Helps measure cups of flour for bread.
Helps measure a doorway with a yardstick to see if a wheelchair will fit.

9BC487FFCE684D63985EF7629EF504C7.description: Uses non-standard units of measurement (e.g., hands, bodies, containers) to estimate measurable attributes.
comments: Measures how many small containers it takes to fill one large container at the water table.
Uses outstretched arms to measure a doorway.
Cuts a piece of yarn they think will be long enough to go around a pumpkin.

32195F9B288D43439AF794723531D05E.description: Compares objects and uses terms such as longer-shorter, hotter-colder, and faster-slower.
comments: Says, "My car is going faster than yours."
Exclaims, "I can't pull the wagon. You're too heavy. Get out!"
Says, "I need a bigger box for these blocks."
The child uses measurement to describe and compare objects in the environment.

590010C61F4846B7B59F98FBDFBA9800.description: Uses charts and graphs to analyze information or answer questions.
comments: Counts number of children who have a pet and do not have a pet to answer the question, "Are there more children in our class who have a pet or who do not have a pet?"
Looks at attendance chart to determine if more boys or girls are present.

DE8439DA3BF04EBBA4A44A8AD39D7F7D.description: Uses descriptive language to compare data in picture graphs or other concrete representations.
comments: Looks at picture graph of selected fruit and says, "A lot of kids like bananas."
Identifies which category has more, fewer, or the same number of objects.

ED8F24EBE0D84ED29BD0C35CC0CE8D0E.description: Displays data to answer simple questions about themselves or the environment.
comments: Makes tally marks representing the number of brothers and sisters they have.
Moves to an area of the room to indicate their vote for the next game to play.
Asks, "What is your favorite color?" Child uses a photo of herself to indicate a favorite color on a class graph.
Surveys the classroom asking, "Do you like chocolate milk or white milk?"
The child collects, organizes, displays, and describes relevant data.

06DFACAF42294F468ACF6C802796A500.description: Explains how items were sorted into groups.
comments: Says, "I put all of these together [helicopter, bee, plane, birds] because they all fly."
Sorts buttons and says, "All these have two holes. These have four holes."

C4A141E40F444756A390DCDD675E5D5A.description: Sorts and classifies objects by one or more attributes (e.g., size, color, shape, texture, use).
comments: Picks all the books about bugs out of the library.
Puts objects together that have the same use; e.g., puts all the vehicles in a pile and all of the blocks in another pile.
Sorts rough and smooth objects into two separate piles.
The child sorts and groups objects by a variety of characteristics/attributes.

6C62642313754D9F9F7C8A7FCBC1BBC9.description: Describes similarities and differences in patterns.
comments: Says, "We always wash our hands after we come in from outside, but today we got a drink first."
Says, "My shirt has two red stripes and one blue stripe, your shirt has one green stripe and one red stripe."
Builds a road alternating long and short unit blocks.
Creates a simple pattern using shells.
Places the next two dominoes, one up and one down when shown a series of dominoes with one up, one down, one up, one down.
Extends a rhythmic pattern: clap, pat, clap, pat.
Matches a pattern on a picture to make a necklace from shaped beads.
Imitates a pattern in a rhythmic activity such as stomp, clap, stomp, clap.

8A290A440B3842A6A733D2E8E6B1D0A2.description: Recognizes patterns in the real world.
comments: Follows and remembers movements in familiar songs and rhymes.
Notices patterns on clothing.
Anticipates what comes next in the daily routine.
The child recognizes, copies, extends, describes and creates patterns.

876E1165C54646DB9E1E08AC72E8A4B8.description: Describes changes in a set of objects when they are separated into parts.
comments: Plays with a plastic ball and bowling pins and tells how many fell down and how many are left standing.
Gives two grapes to a friend and says, "Now I have two grapes and you have two grapes."

6E1D1C791AF94BE3B7A7B3A127470CD4.description: Demonstrates an understanding that taking away decreases the number of objects in a group.
comments: Participates in stories and rhymes involving subtraction; e.g., Five Little Monkeys.
Gives some marbles to a friend and then says, "Now I have less."

FFCCAF6636F7414298D51924FBFCEFB1.description: Describes changes in two or more sets of objects when they are combined.
comments: Recognizes that three cars and two trucks is a total of five vehicles.
Puts the red, yellow, and blue crayons together and tells how many crayons.

2F713AD4E7C6497580545BB666E8BE09.description: Demonstrates an understanding that adding increases the number of objects in a group.
comments: Adds one block to her pile of blocks and says, "Now I have more."
Has one slice of apple on her plate and adds another slice and says, "Now I have two."
Participates in stories and rhymes involving addition; e.g., One Elephant Went Out to Play.
The child combines and separates groups of objects and names how many.

62043EAC708E452695A26BAD20114D20.description: Compares two sets of objects using terms such as more, fewer, or the same.
comments: Looks at friend's blocks and says, "I have more blocks than you."
Matches one car for each toy person to see if there are fewer cars or people.
The child applies a range of strategies such as counting or matching to compare sets of objects.

695BEDBC37A149CBAADB5E5825F236D1.description: Identifies quantity of three-five objects without counting (subitize).
comments: Looks briefly at a picture and says, "There are three ducks."
Looks at a pile of blocks and says, "There are four blocks."

8C0177E68D8C44E0B9005710AEC86600.description: Matches numerals to quantities they represent using physical models and representations.
comments: Spins a spinner, lands on five and moves five steps.
Matches three objects to the numeral three.

446DC4A8276E4D57846AEE5741FE1760.description: Counts a collection of up to 10 items using the last counting word to tell, "How many?"
comments: Counts out six eggs. When adult asks, "How many?" the child responds, "six."
Counts and responds, "seven" when the teacher asks, "How many girls are here today?"

EA551842164745CCB66A05AF3D3970B6.description: Counts groups of objects using one-to-one correspondence (one object for each number word).
comments: Touches and counts the number of cars on the rug, "one, two, three, four, five."
Counts out four straws for the four children at the table.

AA1134440408463CA64582997213A67D.description: Counts to Tell Number of Objects
comments: The child uses number words and counting to identify quantity.
Names some numerals while child is reading a book.
Recognizes numerals in the environment; e.g., signs, grocery store, room numbers.
Points to numerals on his shirt and says, "I have a two and a five on my shirt." (The numerals may or may not be a two and a five.)

D132FB32235A4B1DB8EE5BF1D9AFA944.description: Uses and creates symbols to represent numbers.
comments: Holds up four fingers when asked, "How old are you?"
Writes numerals and numeral-like symbols in the sand.
Writes out a bill while playing restaurant and says, "You owe 10 dollars."

C763B15740194ED5BB393425FF503642.description: Uses numerals and number symbols in the context of daily routines, activities, and play.
comments: Draws a squiggly line and says, "Here is my phone number."
Looks at the grocery advertisement and says, "Oranges are on sale for three dollars."
The child identifies numerals and uses number words in daily activities.
Sings counting songs.
Counts to 10 while playing hide and seek.

761FA4B2D7A64106BC20390E546CD848.description: Shows interest in and awareness of counting.
comments: Participates in counting activities.
Recites numbers one to 10 with increasing accuracy.
The child counts out loud and uses number words in daily conversations.

Mathematics is a way of thinking, knowing, problem-solving, and reasoning that is accessible to all children regardless of their prior knowledge and experiences. From a very early age, mathematics helps children to connect ideas, develop logical thinking, and question, analyze and understand the world around them.

5C26756607C34F51A5358C429F3F64EA.description: Organizes writing from left to right, indicating an awareness that letters cluster as words and words cluster into phrases or sentences by use of spacing or marks.
comments: Plays at writing a message by placing spaces between the "words" on the page.
Writes a series of letters and asks, "What word does this make?"

7B047F3AF89446F5BDED57D0C3776D05.description: With prompting and support, forms letters starting with large motor (sky writing, paint brush and water, sidewalk chalk) progressing to fine motor (paper and pencil).
comments: Writes letters from name on the sidewalk with chalk.
Writes letter-like forms on a page and says, "This is a note for my mommy."

81ABD3F1C1454A24BAA6414142217F35.description: Intentionally uses scribbles/writing and inventive writing to convey meaning, ideas or to tell a story; e.g., signing artwork, captioning, labeling, creating lists, making notes.
comments: While playing restaurant, asks, "What would you like to eat?" and scribbles the order on a pad.
Writes KP OT and says, "This says, 'Keep out."

43FD1769669C4A3E9DFA5819A196930D.description: Writes own name using letter-like forms or conventional print.
comments: Writes own name on drawing.
Writes own name from left to right on the sidewalk when playing with chalk on sidewalk.

F5AE4E1728674396AEDDD33FBA6FB208.description: Dictates to and shares thoughts, ideas, and stories with adults.
comments: Asks adult to write, "This is my dog, we went for a walk" on a drawing.
Asks adult to help him write a sign that says, "Billy made this building. Do not knock it down."

38FB9FEF808944CF8366A85FB476715D.description: With modeling and support, uses a combination of drawing, dictating and emergent writing to communicate an idea or opinion about an experience, story, or book, and to express knowledge or share information about a topic of interest.
comments: Draws random lines/scribbles on a page.
Dictates to an adult a story about her picture.

F565AB64888345A9ACF572C05FE6371C.description: Uses a variety of writing tools, materials, and surfaces to create drawings or symbols.
comments: Draws or writes using pencils, letter stamps, markers, crayons, paint, and/or shaving cream on paper, cardboard, chalkboard, and/or dry erase board.
Draws on the sidewalk with chalk.

0A96705A3A924F29A9A7E1CF30A97824.description: Early Writing, Writing Processes, and Writing Applications
comments: The child uses writing materials to communicate ideas.

C0DBA6A1B9414577AD4320A439FB47AB.description: With modeling and support, demonstrates reading fluency by use of phrasing, intonation and expression in shared reading of familiar books, poems, chants, songs, nursery rhymes or other repetitious or predictable texts.
comments: Repeats phrase in book using appropriate intonation and phrasing "Who's been sitting in my chair?" said Papa Bear.
Says, "Brown Bear, Brown Bear what do you see?" with teacher.

CFD5F88C341C452DAEEEA6960AE2A66A.description: With modeling and support, retells or reenacts a story in sequence with pictures or props.
comments: Acts out a familiar story using dramatic play materials.
Uses felt board to retell story of The Hungry Caterpillar.

DB5BF219CD5E43B9B45F64190114E2A1.description: With modeling and support, identifies the topic of informational text that has been read aloud.
comments: Says "I am going to build a house just like we read about in the book."
Says, "This book tells us how to bake a cake."

DB9BB8374495485D9E43361AFCFBBC17.description: With modeling and support, begins to demonstrate an understanding of the differences between fiction and non-fiction.
comments: Says "Dogs don't talk." after listening to a story about a talking dog.
Gets a Ranger Rick magazine to find information about bears.

E3AEC5AE266C48AB86E56C3580884E2A.description: With prompting and support, gives an opinion for liking or disliking a book or story.
comments: Says, "I like that book because David is funny."
Says, "I don't like that book because it is scary."

2D33FF4921E74761A12107D28356B7BA.description: With prompting and support, identifies events and details in the story and makes predictions.
comments: Predicts what happens next in a story.
Says, "I think the story will be about frogs." after completing a picture walk of a book.

FEF4D1353AF943E198AB2DFCC573668E.description: With prompting and support, draws connections between story events and personal experiences.
comments: Exclaims, "I have a cat!" after hearing a story about pets.
Says, "We went sledding in Flagstaff." after reading The Snowy Day.

F6036D591FDC4851992C5FA48FAE2050.description: With prompting and support, asks and answers a variety of questions about books or stories told or read aloud.
comments: Asks, "Where do whales live?" after hearing a story about whales.
Declares, "I think David should make a better choice." when teacher asks, "What would you tell David?"

1DC3DE32A4F04A4E805F5B325C267599.description: With prompting and support, identifies characters and major events in a story.
comments: Provides details about the characters and actions after listening to a story.
Tells adult the wolf blew the house down.

41AC07FB54D941C29F43EB4868BC47E2.description: Takes an active role in reading activities.
comments: Picks up a book and pretends to read.
Chooses a book and asks someone to read it.
The child shows an interest in books and comprehends books read aloud with increasing text complexity.

C0E1C90E66724DA89C42EBE29CABBE90.description: Uses letter-sound knowledge identifying the sounds of a few letters and producing the correct sounds for as many as 10 letters, with modeling and support.
comments: While writing the child's name, Taylor makes the "t" sound and then prints the letter.
Says, "/S/, /s/, /s/, snake." when looking at a letter [S].

912062BEF2824506A10A3BD26A0A6349.description: Recognizes as many as 10 letters, especially those in own name, family and friends.
comments: Correctly names some letters while playing with alphabet stamps, magnets, cards, or puzzles.
Says, "My name starts with an [I]."

79DD7EFE51E840A08B636E6CD5CED688.description: Matches and recognizes similarities and differences in letters, with modeling and support.
comments: Points to the upper case 'E' and the upper case 'F' and says, "This one [F] lost a line."
Points to the letters s, g, o, and c and says, "These letters have curves."
Says, "My name starts with a big A." The teacher says, "Yes, your name starts with an upper case A."

552B66AF38E94E0097393175D7A40290.description: Discriminates letters from other shapes and symbols.
comments: Points to the letter [a] and says, "This is the letter a." when given a choice between letters and numbers.
Points to the numeral two and says, "This is not a letter."
The child demonstrates knowledge of the alphabet.

314ADBC553F74848A2955D16C258CF07.description: With modeling and support, repeats words and identifies the common final sound.
comments: Identifies the common ending sound when shown pictures of mat, kite, and boat.
The teacher and child repeat the word bat three times. The child then says, "Bat has a /t/ sound at the end."

BC59A2750CB342BBBC6243F722BA32AB.description: With modeling and support, combines onset and rime to form a familiar one-syllable word with and without pictorial support.
comments: Selects the correct picture of the cat when the adult says the name by segmenting it into its onset and rime components, /c/ + /at/.
Guesses, "Dog." when teacher says the onset and rime /d/ /og/.

20FD21D746BF45688490658E31CF29F6.description: With modeling and support, identifies and discriminates syllables in words.
comments: Claps each syllable of a name during a name game or name song. (Ben-ja-min = clap, clap, clap)
Takes a step for each syllable heard in a word. (ad-ven-ture = step, step, step)

924B63AD1D07408EB960D57FF683A504.description: Hears and shows awareness of separate words within spoken phrases or sentences.
comments: Claps each word spoken in a sentence "I like blocks."
Jumps when hearing a specified word in a story/poem.

E013000D335A4EBEA0E60D6F484E398A.description: With modeling and support, recognizes spoken words that begin with the same sound.
comments: Child named Maria says, "My name starts like Monique's name."
Selects man and mop as beginning with the same sound when presented with pictures of man, hat and mop.

4E59038A49FB4243B01C7DE81B6CB7CB.description: With modeling and support, produces rhyming words.
comments: Child whose name is Joy, while playing, spontaneously says, "Joy, noy, boy, loy, toy."
Finishes the rhyme "The fat cat sat on the ____."

793AA5B20DA3415DAE8539FB0694AC16.description: With modeling and support, identifies rhyming words.
comments: Shows thumbs up when two words rhyme in a poem, cat/hat.
Points to pictures of words that rhyme.

0B710E2266264C3CBB42DFCE938C642B.description: Differentiates between sounds that are the same and different (e.g., environmental sounds, animal sounds, phonemes).
comments: Plays sound bingo and can differentiate between sounds – "That's a telephone. That's a car horn."
Says, "Hey the beginning of my name sounds like that /t/."
The child develops awareness that language can be broken in words, syllables, and smaller units of sounds (phonemes).

103AFDB0D060446CBEEBDA0750E141FA.description: Understands a book has a title, author and/or illustrator.
comments: Makes a book and says, "My book is called My Mom and I'm the author."
Identifies that the illustrator draws the pictures in a book.

620AA412D92443B6AAF585E77E583284.description: Identifies where in the book to begin reading.
comments: Finds the front of the book, the first page of the text, and the first word on the page.
Points to the first page and says, "Start here."

A0CF6095D732433E8D52D22DCF98767E.description: Holds a book right side up with the front cover facing the reader and understands left to right and top to bottom directionality.
comments: Turns the pages one page at a time in order to continue reading.
Turns the book right side up before beginning to look at it, when handed a book upside down.
The child demonstrates how to handle books appropriately and with care.
Says, "We caught a cricket in our bug jar. Let's find a book about crickets."
Looks at grocery advertisements while creating a shopping list.

8A919731EA3A4EE3A17BE1FD30FF4F9B.description: Recognizes own written name and the written names of friends and family.
comments: Reads job chart naming his classmates.
Picks up a name card and says, "This says Jose."

332B163785B84B84A89EB9D4E8A7630F.description: Recognizes that letters are grouped to form words.
comments: Asks teacher to write name on her paper.
Groups letters together and asks, "What does this say?"

2420E0F5A2D142CF91D08C4CA460AB98.description: Demonstrates and understands that print conveys meaning and that each spoken word can be written and read.
comments: Finds name on her placemat at lunch.
Pretends to read a letter while playing Post Office.

559AFC97394F4D71A22B7FEB41C4206B.description: Identifies signs, symbols and labels in the environment.
comments: Points to a McDonalds sign and says, "That says McDonalds."
Sees recycling symbol and says, "This is the recycling bin."
The child knows that print carries messages.

EC0282AAAB5A43A5892208D7A2FC846D.description: With modeling and support, demonstrates understanding of and uses words that indicate position and direction; e.g., in, on, out, under, off, beside, behind.
comments: Responds to the teacher's requests to put his car on the shelf, blocks in the container, or stand beside a peer.
Says, "I am standing between Billy and Rita."

3CB394FC66FE4BDBA958D0AA25FE62F0.description: With modeling and support, uses category labels and names objects within a category; e.g., fruit, vegetable, animal, transportation, etc.
comments: Says, "I want a carrot and broccoli." when asked what vegetables she wants.
Gathers and names a fire truck, car, and dump truck when asked to put vehicles in the block area.

661623B449FB408F87DD76177DC1FA06.description: With modeling and support, determines the meanings of unknown words and concepts using the context of conversations, pictures that accompany text or concrete object.
comments: Says, "A skyscraper is a tall building." after the teacher shows them a book about buildings.
Says, "I will get the colander to rinse the grapes." after using the colander during a group cooking activity with the teacher.

0F61C9A6F48F44C4B257FB9860970999.description: With modeling and support, uses age-appropriate vocabulary across many topic areas and demonstrates a wide variety of words and their meanings with each area; e.g., world knowledge, names of body parts, feelings, colors, shapes, jobs, plants, animals and their habitats, and foods; words that describe: adjectives, verbs, and adverbs.
comments: Says, "Let me listen to your heart with a stethoscope." while in dramatic play.
Exclaims, "I'm so mad, I'm going to explode like a volcano!"
The child understands and uses increasingly complex vocabulary.

0B5FE090E47440B6B917510345090A3A.description: With modeling and support, uses increasingly complex phrases and sentences.
comments: Says, "Let's put the cars up higher on the ramp so they will go really fast."
Says, "I want to go home because my grandma is there."

17332FA6EB91476FBFC9ED46E9FCE279.description: Recognizes when the listener does not understand and uses techniques to clarify the message.
comments: Uses a different word to clarify the intended message when child realizes he has been misunderstood.
Points to a picture to clarify his intent.

E646D552B9114713AD79082ACDCF646A.description: Uses appropriate eye contact, turn taking, and intonation while having conversations with adults and peers.
comments: Uses turn-taking during conversations with peers and adults.
Looks at a friend as she is speaking.

7279B05AF9894FDF84C31CD08B31EC72.description: With modeling and support, uses acceptable language and social rules including appropriate tone, volume and inflection to express ideas, feelings, and needs.
comments: With reminder, child uses inside voice when going into the classroom.
Child emphatically tells a classmate, "Stop, I don't like that!" or Whispers in a classmate's ear during circle time.

CA94C1D0D9BB42A4A174F5F7B9ADD407.description: Initiates, sustains, and expands conversations with peers and adults.
comments: Approaches peers and asks, "What are you making?"

Says "I went to the zoo." Teacher expands by asking, "What was your favorite animal?" Child replies, "The lion." Teacher responds, "The lion is your favorite. Why?" Child answers, "I like the way he roars."

97E4AFA947CA471D8AF2879534FA21C0.description: Makes relevant responses to questions and comments from others.
comments: Exclaims, "I did it!" after teachers asks, "Did you get your jacket on?"
Says, "I have a cat, too," after teacher shows a picture of a cat.

0D7B538478BB4D31A2C6267994B91FA2.description: Speaks clearly and understandably to express ideas, feelings and needs.
comments: Combines words into simple sentences – "Is it time to go home?" Or "More milk please."
Says, "I want to go build in the block area."

524B2EE882154BB980D430B1B3523970.description: Communicates needs, wants, ideas, and feelings through three to five word sentences.
comments: Intentionally engages in conversations with peers and adults at snack time replying to the question, "What did you have for breakfast?" "My mom made pancakes."
When someone is talking about a trip to a park, another child signs, "I went to the park too. We had a picnic."
The child uses verbal and nonverbal communication for a variety of purposes to share observations, ideas, and experiences, problem-solve, reason, predict and seek new information.

7C5AA820B5FC48AC840C188311C008ED.description: Demonstrates understanding and follows directions that involve: one step, two steps, and a series of unrelated sequences of action.
comments: Responds to directions, "Put the block on the table, put your paper in the cubby, and line up to go outside."
Places toy truck on shelf when adult says, "Please put the truck on the shelf."

A0ADA20FA2454411A0E317FE8A4DFEB6.description: Actively engages in finger-plays, rhymes, chants, poems, conversations, and stories.
comments: Claps when prompted with, "If you're happy and you know it, clap your hands."
Participates in story Going on a Bear Hunt.

D3C9E7953DC24ADE9269D03AC9BE985A.description: Demonstrates understanding of a variety of finger-plays, rhymes, chants, poems, conversations, and stories.
comments: Follows gestures and actions.
Points to blocks when asked, "It's time to work. Where would you like to play?" Teacher expands on child's response by saying, "Oh, you want to play in the block area."
The child demonstrates understanding of directions, stories, and conversations.

Daily exposure to verbal and written language provides young children with the opportunities to begin acquiring understanding of the concepts of literacy and its functions. Through play and intentional activities, children learn to create meaning from language and communicate with others using verbal and non-verbal language, pictures, symbols and print.

1F28F84B2365492CBA6D24F155151CAB.description: Works to solve a problem independently.
comments: When ropes on the swing become tangled, child works to untangle them.
Child gets a step stool to help him reach the paper towels.
When child discovers paint on her pants, she gets a wet paper towel and wipes the paint off.
Child asks another child to hold the door open while he parks his bike in the shed.

3543B18995A34AD7BFD12F5F7BEBDB0B.description: Seeks adult assistance when support is required.
comments: When putting on her jacket, the child asks, "Will you zip my jacket, please?"
Child attempts to open paint container. When he is unable to do so, he asks for help.
When setting the table, child realizes there are not enough cups and says, "We have a problem. There are not enough cups."
Two children want to play with the red truck. One says, "We both can't play with it."
The child demonstrates the ability to seek solutions to problems.

51D74B60DA1E4CF88A1B086842AFB15D.description: Uses prior knowledge to build new knowledge and skills.
comments: Child mixed yellow and red to make orange on Monday. On Tuesday he states, "I'm going to mix purple and orange to make a new color!"
After going to the zoo, the child builds a structure in blocks to house the animals.

8CD0E3EC56E54A18980C4E5C487407E2.description: Recognizes relationships between cause and effect.
comments: While playing on the computer, the child intentionally clicks on the mouse to change the screen.
Child increases the slant of the ramp in order to make the marble go faster.

A677A382B2BF4E2F9999BAE180FF235A.description: Gathers information and reaches a conclusion.
comments: Child notices his friend is not present and states, "Billy isn't here. He must be sick."
During an experiment with ice, child states, "It melted! It must be because it's not as cold in here as it is in the freezer."
The child demonstrates the ability to analyze information and situations in order to form judgments.
While playing house with a friend, child says, "Let's take the babies to the park."
During center time a child says to her friend, "Let's use these boxes to build a rocket and go to the moon!"
Child reacts with a laugh or smile when something silly occurs in the story. Child says, "That is a funny story."
Child shows enjoyment while stringing nonsense words together, such as; "link, pink, stink, frink, gink…"

D77E8F4702DB4FC9944ADBDEDA02510D.description: Uses imagination to generate new ideas.
comments: Child creates a story about a picture she has drawn.
During transition, child suggests, "How about we walk like turtles to the playground!"
The child demonstrates the ability to express their own unique way of seeing the world.

A0642010CFD14040BE93A1085EDCEC16.description: Is willing to take risks and consider a variety of alternatives.
comments: When offered "broccoli and ranch dressing," the child says, "I want to try it."
The child chooses the high heel shoes and walks around the classroom despite his friends saying, "Boys don't wear those shoes."

FEFA573BBD4043D0862FD14DAD7FE737.description: Views self as competent and skilled.
comments: The child says, "I can pour the juice myself."
Child tells his friend, "I don't want you to help. I can do it!"
Child indicates red is her favorite color and then chooses it even though her peers chose other colors.
While building a castle, the child says to his friend, "I know how to get the top to stay on."
The child demonstrates self-assurance in a variety of circumstances.

25B88200AC9947629DF4AF53897DFEFF.description: Establishes goals, generates plans and follows through to completion.
comments: Child works on building a Lego airport throughout the course of the day.
Child works on creating a 3-D art project based on his drawing.

0045159F173F4D81AC09CD2BB4CB0DD5.description: Copes with frustration or disappointment with support.
comments: While trying to pour juice into a cup, the child knocks the cup over, resets the cup and tries again.
Child wants to use the computer and others are already there. She adds her name to the list so she can use the computer later.
Child continuously stacks blocks to duplicate a picture until they no longer tumble down.
Child practices swinging across the monkey bars until successful.
The child demonstrates the ability to maintain and sustain a challenging task.

6AF1DA8FDD614EBF80F01B0024A4FACF.description: Increases ability to focus attention, and can return to activities after distractions and interruptions.
comments: The child stops his activity to join in a problem-solving discussion at the teacher's request and then returns to his art activity.
The child returns to a construction project over several days, adding new dimensions each day.

B64D78BD66804BCCA0E7D2088E37BD56.description: Sustains attention for extended periods of time when engaged in an age-appropriate activity despite distractions or interruptions.
comments: The child focuses on making a menu for the pizza parlor while others are rolling clay to make pizzas.
The child continues to work on a puzzle even with other children playing musical instruments nearby.

743F5C6BFC834FCBAF25940C9C371417.description: Displays ability to hold attention when engaged in an activity.
comments: The child claps every time she hears the /m/ sound in a poem as directed by the teacher.
During a transition, the child waits for the teacher to call his name and shows the color he is wearing before he goes to wash his hands.
The child demonstrates the ability to focus on an activity with deliberate concentration despite distractions.
When going on a walk, the child asks, "Where are we going?"
After listening to a story about a dog, child asks, "What kind of dog do you have?"
Child says, "I wonder where Jack and Jill are today?"
Child asks, "Do you have any sisters?"

E4A214D8BD214D9B9CA77D83A5D7FB55.description: Shows interest in learning new things and trying new experiences.
comments: Child says, "Ohhhh, what does that do?" when a microscope is brought into the room for the first time.
Child gets a magnifying glass to look at a rock.
The child demonstrates eagerness to learn about and discuss a range of topics, ideas, and activities.

F4E8FA3478CE4C49801E17F7A3A0D56D.description: Exhibits cognitive flexibility, imagination, and inventiveness when attempting tasks and activities.
comments: While playing in the block area with friends, child goes to the library to get a book on buildings. He returns to the block area to show friends a picture of a structure they can build.
Child tries different ways to make a design using pattern blocks, combining two shapes to make a new shape.

DA7C96C75D5D453592759EB494033C57.description: Develops independence during activities, routines and play.
comments: Upon entering the learning environment, the child hangs up his coat and backpack.
Child gathers needed items to paint at the easel (paint, brush, paper, smock).
While playing outside, child asks a friend to play with her on the slide.
Child joins three other children to play in the sand.
The child demonstrates self-direction while participating in a range of activities and routines.
Approaches to learning refer to observable behaviors that indicate ways children become engaged in social interactions and learning experiences.

087279F6A27944BDAE31D25B992492DE.description: Shows respect for learning materials in the learning environment.
comments: Reminds classmates to take care of the books.
Picks up crayons from the floor and returns them to the correct container.

C4FCE18DC7C6431E921BBD67AE04753D.description: Defends own rights and the rights of others.
comments: Tells his friend not to knock down his block structure.
Says, "Elizabeth, Joe had the bike first."

6686E3273C074EBAA175180FD017BF01.description: Respects the rights and property of others.
comments: Walks around a block structure built by another child.
Sees a doll in another child's backpack and asks to play with it.
The child acknowledges the rights and property of self and others.

04CF1963A22446FFA4E7AA2D3E55EE1D.description: Demonstrates positive ways to resolve conflict.
comments: Asks for a turn when they want a toy another child is playing with.
Seeks assistance from a teacher before a disagreement starts to escalate into physical aggression.

DFCBFAC0DCB94C3080B0F03275766BBF.description: Initiates and sustains positive interactions with adults and other children.
comments: Asks teacher to help finish putting a puzzle together.
Suggests, "Let's build a road for our cars." Children work together to build a road.

7CE54B6561C1439AADDED8CBA6CAE407.description: Responds when adults or other children initiate interactions.
comments: Chooses from the choice board when asked, "What do you want to do now?"
Joins a group when invited to play.
The child displays socially competent behavior.

21E10EEBB9154CA68F768F75B52A0050.description: Separates from familiar adult with minimal distress.
comments: Continues to paint after acknowledging a family member's arrival.
Cries briefly or doesn't cry when dropped off at school or child care provider's home.

7F1C2C561C3241DF965BC56057D16E33.description: Demonstrates the ability to engage with new adults or children with the support of familiar adults.
comments: Invites a new student to join in the activity.
Looks to familiar adult for reassurance when approached by an unfamiliar adult.

6352B40F26A6428D9887958C6E9C777C.description: Seeks security and support from familiar adults.
comments: Yells out for a teacher when they need help.
Seeks out the caregiver when they get hurt.
Greets parent upon arrival with a hug or a high-five.
Leans on teacher when reading a book.
The child demonstrates the ability to engage in and maintain healthy relationships.
Says "Stop, I don't like it when you hit me." When a peer hits her.
Waits for her turn during a conversation.

946768E6EF724197AAB7D0D9247DEA3B.description: Modifies behavior for various situations and settings.
comments: Uses a quiet voice when visiting the library.
Withdraws to a safe place to calm down after an altercation with another child.

076597C306A94AE18DEA00A3D117A6B5.description: Manages transitions, daily routines and unexpected events.
comments: Moves to the next activity independently.
Stays with the group and follows the teacher during a fire drill.

DDE3E16B2EC94619AAEBD42D268A61C2.description: Understands and follows expectations in the learning environment.
comments: Reminds others that running is for outside.
Puts his puzzle away when "Clean Up Time" is announced.
The child manages the expression of feelings, thoughts, impulses and behaviors.
Sees her friend crying, and then gives her a hug.
Asks, "Are you OK?" after seeing her friend fall down.

9ADD202D76CF49288C4A1CE14E6EFA6E.description: Identifies and describes feelings of others.
comments: Approaches an adult and says, "Jamal is sad. He is crying."
Says, "My mommy will be so excited to see my picture!"

9CDF5334974E4C95AD62DCF1A7AE715E.description: Identifies, describes and expresses their own feelings.
comments: Covers their eyes and says, "This is scary!" while listening to a story.
Says, "I am happy today because it's my birthday!"

34AD5CAD86D545A0A912E9DA835001A1.description: Associates emotions with words, facial expressions and body language.
comments: Describes the emotions of a character in a book.
Signs, "I am mad" when asked how she feels.
The child recognizes and expresses feelings of self and others.

45CF115479DD46AD9A1E33301B92A0E9.description: Shows an awareness of similarities and differences between self and others.
comments: Says, "I am bigger than you."
Points to his shirt and then to his friend's shirt, indicating that they are wearing the same color of shirt.
Declares, "I'm the big brother," while looking at a family picture.
Holds up three fingers and says "I am this many."

AAA40BBE0C0D4154A98B38BCF2764703.description: Makes personal preferences known to others.
comments: Signs "red," when asked to name a favorite color.
Tells her friends, "I don't like that."
Acknowledges her own accomplishments and says, "I can hit the ball."
Tells the teacher, "I can do it myself."
The child demonstrates an awareness of his or her self.
Children learn and thrive within relationships in which they feel emotionally secure and physically safe.
